name: Structured Numeric
description: The SN data type is used to represent numeric values with comparison operators, ranges, or other structured numeric relationships. It supports expressions like '>5.0', '<10.0', '5.0-10.0' commonly found in laboratory results, reference ranges, and clinical measurements. SN provides a standardized way to encode numeric values that include relational operators, inequalities, and numeric ranges essential for clinical interpretation.

SN.1.name: Comparator
SN.1.description: The comparison operator that precedes or relates to the numeric value. Specifies the relationship (e.g., <, >, <=, >=, =, +, -, :).

SN.2.name: Num1
SN.2.description: The first or primary numeric value. This contains the main measurement value or the first value in a range.

SN.3.name: Separator/Suffix
SN.3.description: A separator character for ranges (e.g., '-' for ranges) or suffix for the numeric value. Used to separate ranges or indicate special numeric notations.

SN.4.name: Num2
SN.4.description: The second numeric value, typically used for ranges. Contains the upper bound when expressing numeric ranges.

constraints.logicalConsistency: When used for ranges, Num1 should typically be less than or equal to Num2
constraints.operatorValidity: Comparator should be a valid comparison operator
constraints.contextualMeaning: The combination of components should form a meaningful numeric expression

usage: Laboratory result values with comparison operators
Vital sign ranges and critical values
commonFields: OBX.5 - Observation Value for numeric results with operators
OBX.7 - References Range for normal value ranges
Laboratory result fields requiring comparison operators

generationHints.typical: Use realistic clinical values with appropriate comparison operators
generationHints.labValues: Generate reference ranges appropriate for common lab tests
generationHints.ranges: Use clinically meaningful ranges for different measurement types
generationHints.precision: Match decimal precision to clinical requirements

validationRules.operatorValidation: SN.1 should contain valid comparison operators
validationRules.numericValidation: SN.2 and SN.4 must be valid numeric values when populated
validationRules.rangeLogic: For ranges, SN.2 should typically be less than SN.4
validationRules.separatorConsistency: SN.3 should be appropriate for the type of expression
validationRules.clinicalReasonableness: Values should be within reasonable clinical ranges

interpretationContext.abnormalFlags: Indicates when values are outside normal ranges
interpretationContext.referenceRanges: Provides normal value ranges for comparison
interpretationContext.qualityControl: Defines acceptable limits for quality control

relatedDataTypes.NM: Numeric - for simple numeric values without operators
relatedDataTypes.ST: String - used for comparison operators and separators
relatedDataTypes.CQ: Composite Quantity with Units - for numeric values with units
relatedDataTypes.CE: Coded Element - for coded abnormal flags and interpretations

implementationNotes.parsing: Requires careful parsing to interpret the structured numeric expression
implementationNotes.display: Should render meaningfully for clinical users (e.g., '>5.0', '5.0-10.0')
implementationNotes.comparison: Enable comparison operations for clinical decision support
implementationNotes.ranges: Support range checking and validation against reference values
implementationNotes.precision: Maintain appropriate numeric precision for clinical accuracy

clinicalSignificance.diagnosis: Critical for interpreting laboratory results and measurements
clinicalSignificance.monitoring: Essential for tracking patient progress and therapeutic response
clinicalSignificance.alerting: Enables automated alerting for critical values and abnormal results
clinicalSignificance.trending: Supports trending analysis of patient measurements over time
clinicalSignificance.research: Facilitates clinical research and population health analysis

interoperabilityConsiderations.standardization: Provides consistent representation of numeric relationships
interoperabilityConsiderations.interpretation: Enables automated interpretation of clinical values
interoperabilityConsiderations.integration: Supports integration with clinical decision support systems
interoperabilityConsiderations.reporting: Facilitates standardized clinical reporting and documentation
